entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights
entry.content:
Q2 brought a wave of innovations to SAP Build, including improvements across governance, integration and user experience. We also had several announcements in the spotlight at SAP Sapphire 2025 around new AI capabilities, unified pricing, and of course Joule Studio, which lets you create custom Joule skills and AI agents. In case you missed it, check out our roundup of key updates from SAP Sapphire and the announcement of Joule Studio.

If you‚Äôre interested in shaping the future of SAP Build, we‚Äôve introduced the SAP Build Discovery Initiative 2025. We‚Äôre looking for participants to meet with product teams, test early prototypes and bring your perspective to influence innovations from day one. Find more info here.

Now let‚Äôs dive into the Top 10 release innovations from Q2 2025!

Enhanced governance capabilities

1. Empowering business users to maintain rules through an application

In Process Automation projects, business users are often the content owners of decisions and the logic behind business rules. While the SAP Build Lobby is a powerful environment, it can also be challenging to navigate and maintain the content of separate artifacts. 

Now IT and dev teams can give business users access to decisions via a purpose-built application, which is opened in SAP Build Work Zone. By empowering business users to access the logic this way, it helps mitigate risks of unauthorized changes, while also reducing delays around the change management process.

Manage decisions through a purpose-built application

2. Improved governance with approval flows & multi-node project transport

Strong governance frameworks are essential to ensure that your development activities remain secure and compliant. We have now released two features that support greater control and quality assurance:

  • Governance approval flows: This enables administrators to control who is authorized to create or transport projects across tenants or sub-accounts. The approval process is fully customizable, allowing organizations to implement quality gates aligned with their specific governance and compliance requirements.
  • Multi-node project transport: Approvers can now move SAP Build projects (apps, processes, automations) through a controlled Dev -> Test -> Production landscape, with approval steps and quality checks at each stage. This ensures dev teams are moving projects securely and efficiently across tenants.

Governance approval flows

Seamless interoperability and AI-powered integration

3. Importing Business Process Model & Notation (BPMN) to generate process artifacts automatically 

Great news for our automation enthusiasts ‚Äì it‚Äôs now possible to import BPMN processes from other tools into SAP Build! BPMN is the industry standard for defining workflows, decisions, and interactions across systems and teams. 

Now process designers can migrate existing BPMN processes from SAP Signavio, SAP NetWeaver, and IBM to generate process artifacts automatically. This long-awaited transportability helps to speed up the logic creation significantly, as well as acting as the bridge between SAP Build and other process modeling tools. 

To get started with BPMN process imports, see the Help Portal.Import BPMN processes into SAP Build

4. Improved SAP SuccessFactors integration with event discovery

From the SAP Build Lobby, developers can manage and connect SAP and non-SAP systems through the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL). Now in the UCL, developers can discover business events from SAP Cloud Application Event Hub, as well as SAP SuccessFactors solutions. This improved integration supports more relevant scenarios for HR processes, such as employee onboarding and compensation management. 

5. AI grounding in company-specific content for tailored responses

This feature makes it possible to base Joule copilot and other embedded AI capabilities on up-to-date documents and user-created content in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the RAG (retrieval augmented generation) method. Rather than giving generic responses, it provides end users with more accurate and domain-specific content.

AI grounding within Joule copilot

6. Joule-based assistant to easily migrate SAP HANA applications to CAP

For simplified innovation across services, the SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant is a new extension available in SAP Build Code. This automates the conversion of XS classic applications into CAP-based services to accelerate modernization and help businesses adopt cloud-native architectures faster.

For more info, see Product Updates for SAP Build Code ‚Äì June 2025 Edition

Optimized user experience and accessibility across devices

7. SAP Mobile Start as the unified mobile access point for users

SAP Mobile Start addresses the challenge of fragmented access to enterprise applications and information for mobile users. The connection of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition ensures that users have consistent and secure access to business applications, tasks, and notifications, regardless of their location or device.

 8. Preview SAPUI5 updates for better UX management

To address the need for more controlled testing, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. Admins can activate the preview in a staging or dev tenant, validate compatibility and confirm everything works as expected before go-live ‚Äì ensuring agile development, reduced downtime, and better user experience management.

For more info, read the blog post.

SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

9. Local Entry Point (LEP) to simplify access to standalone sites

The new Local Entry Point (LEP) concept of SAP Build Work Zone simplifies how SaaS application providers integrate business solutions into SAP BTP. Providers can generate a standalone entry-point site in the consumer‚Äôs subaccount, eliminating the extra efforts and complexity required to set up their own instances.

To get started, see the Help Portal.

10. Updates to Mobile Development Kit for enhanced UI, APIs and more

The latest release to SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) has brought several new updates for customers, including the newest version of Mobile Services Client in the Google Play Store and Apple App Store. Among the newest enhancements to UI is support for donut charts, providing a new way to visualize data and emphasize different aspects of datasets.

See all the latest updates: What‚Äôs New in Mobile Development Kit client 25.6

Ready to see these in action?

To learn more and see live demos of the latest release highlights, join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 Webinar! 

üëâRegister for your preferred time slot:

  • July 17th, 9:00AM ‚Äì 10:00AM CEST: https://sap.to/60414diDL
  • July 17th, 5:00PM ‚Äì 6:00PM CEST: https://sap.to/60434diDF

entry.title: SAP Developer News July 3rd, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST:  https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/07/03/sap-developer-news-july-3rd-2025/ 

Code Connect 2025 event app now available 

  • Event app https://code-connect.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/#/event  

What‚Äôs New in SAP Build, Q2 2025 

  • Esmee‚Äôs blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/what-s-new-in-sap-build-q2-2025-release-highlights/ba-p/14142487 
  • SAP Build Discovery Initiative 2025 (sign up to give your feedback): https://go4.events.sap.com/builddiscovery/en_us/home.html 
  • What‚Äôs New Webinar: 
  • July 17, 9:00 CEST: https://sap.to/60414diDL 
  • July 17, 17:00 CEST: https://sap.to/60434diDF 
  • Importing BPMN: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/import-bpmn-process 
  • Governance Rules: https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules 
  • Decisions UI (Studio Home): https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/use-studio-home and Shrini‚Äôs news item at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q73gDfWwp-c&list=PL6RpkC85SLQAVBSQXN9522_1jNvPavBgg&index=5&t=89s  

July's developer challenge in SAP Community 

  • SAP Community Escape House for July ‚Äì SAP Cloud Application Event Hub ‚öΩÔ∏è üèÜ üèüÔ∏è: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/sap-community-escape-house-for-july-sap-cloud-application-event-hub-%EF%B8%8F-%EF%B8%8F/ba-p/14140520  
  • SAP Community Escape House: https://sap-community-escape-house.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/house  

Marc Bernard: abapGit v1.132.0 is out 

  • Marc Bernard Bluesky post: https://bsky.app/profile/marcf.be/post/3lsgbadkh3k2d 
  • https://github.com/abapGit/abapGit/blob/main/changelog.txt 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 Code Connect 2025 event app now available 

1:07 What‚Äôs New in SAP Build, Q2 2025 

3:20 July's developer challenge in SAP Community 

3:59 Marc Bernard: abapGit v1.132.0 is out 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for July the 3rd, 2025.

[DJ] Code Connect is just around the corner. Next week, in fact, after a pre-event kickoff with two Code Jams, one on UI5 and one on CAP, we hit the ground running with UI5Con on Tuesday, Recap on Wednesday, and HANATechCon on Thursday. That's a lot of sessions, a lot of topics, a lot of everything. So it's great that the CodeConnect app is now available with everything you need to know, including details on speakers, sponsors, the venue, guides on how to attend on-site and also remotely via streaming, an agenda builder and lots more. The best thing? It's available on desktop and on your phone because it's a native app, web native of course. what else the link to the app no install required is in the description.

[Daniel] the quarterly what's new for SAP build was released this week here is a sampling of what's new first you can help shape the future of SAP build by joining the SAP build discovery initiative 2025, where you can have monthly calls and one-on-one sessions for research interviews and user testing, as well as discussions where you can provide your feedback directly to SAP Build Development. I'll leave a link where you can register for these sessions. Second, you can now import BPMN compliant processes like those you might create in Signavio or NetWeaver or IBM directly into SAP Build. Just open up a project and click the import button. There'll be an option for BPMN processes. BPMN is an ISO standard for specifying business processes graphically. Third, SAP Build is always adding governance features, too worth mentioning. You can now create governance rules to control who has permission to create projects, as well as transport them from dev to QA to production. And as my colleague Shrini mentioned a couple weeks ago you can now provide business users a simplified UI in work zone to update decisions without having to open up the entire project and redeploy it there are also features related to creating UI5 projects CAP projects working with mobile development kit mobile start as well as integrating with SuccessFactors. You can learn about all of the features through two webinars scheduled for later in July. In the description, I will supply links to register for those webinars, to register for the feedback sessions, to Esmee‚Äôs blog, as well as all the features that I mentioned today.

[Antonio] Hola, SAP developers. July's Developer Challenge is now available in the SAP community. This month is all about events between SAP Cloud Applications, specifically the BTP service called SAP Cloud Application Event Hub. I highly recommend checking it out, as you will learn how to get started with Event Hub, what's required to set it up, and different important concepts which will help you in your integration scenarios. Similar to previous developer challenges, an SAP Community Batch will be awarded to all participants who complete the challenge. I hope you like it. Ciao!

[Mamikee] ABAP Git version 1.13.0 is officially bringing out powerful updates for ABAP developers. In this release, you can now move repositories to a different SAP package, use ABAP language version support for more object types, view all transports for objects logged across multiple requests, access full support for LXE translations, and also benefit from a number of bug fixes and performance enhancements. These updates were announced by Mark Bernard and you can find the full changelog and his post linked in the description below. Make sure to update your local ABAP Git installation and take advantage of these improvements.

entry.title: Collaborate on the Next Evolution of SAP BTP: Join the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative 2025-2
entry.content:
SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) is transforming how enterprises innovate. As a unified platform that brings together application development, automation, data and analytics, integration, and AI, SAP BTP enables businesses to unlock new levels of efficiency and intelligence - all while maximizing the value of their SAP investments.

Now, imagine being part of that transformation.

The second cycle of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative for 2025 has just launched and it‚Äôs your chance to influence the future of SAP BTP. As a customer or partner, you‚Äôre invited to directly engage with SAP developers and product teams to help shape upcoming features, tools, and innovations.

This is more than just early insights - it‚Äôs a chance to influence the future of enterprise technology.

But don‚Äôt wait - registration is open only until July 25, 2025.

You can sign up to collaborate on one or more of the following active projects:

  • Apply your brand to SAP applications using the UI theme designer
  • Automation and AI in SAP Discovery Center
  • Building BTP Solutions effectively with AI-augmented Infrastructure as Code Generation
  • Enhancing the User Experience of SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery
  • Flexible Cost Allocations using SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Universal Model
  • IT Financial Management Cost Allocation Module in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud
  • Logging Feedback Day - SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime
  • Making your business future ready for Agentic AI - reimagining application development on BTP
  • Operational Transfer Pricing Optimization in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud
  • SAP Build - Discovery Initiative
  • Strategic Planning Scenarios in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Universal Model
  • The Future of Autonomous Software Engineering (ASE) in the Enterprise Context
  • Using a Custom Theme Across SAP Platforms and Systems

Let‚Äôs shape the future together!

Innovation happens through collaboration. By participating in the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative projects, you help SAP create better, more relevant solutions for businesses like yours. This is your chance to influence what comes next.

Don‚Äôt miss out ‚Äì sign up today at influence.sap.com and be a part of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Cycle 2 in 2025!

Warm regards, 
Your SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Team 

Follow-up after registration: When you register for a project, you will be invited to an introductory call‚ÄØwith the SAP project lead. At this point further participation is optional. Typically, all activities are governed by the‚ÄØFeedback Agreement with SAP.

entry.title: Automating Email with SAP Build Process Automation and Outlook Bot
entry.content:
In this blog, I will walk you through how I built an outlook automation bot that : -
i) Opens Microsoft Outlook.
ii) Sends a repetitive message with  .docx file attached.
iii) Closes outlook.
iv) Is released and deployed through the SAP Build lobby.

Creating a new automation project
First of all log into SAP Build Lobby.
Click create -> Automated Process->Automation and click on next


Name your project as ‚ÄòOutlookEmailAutomation‚Äô.
Provide a short description  as ‚Äú Bot to send daily emails with attachment via outlook‚Äù.

Click on ‚ÄòReview‚Äô and then ‚ÄòCreate‚Äô.

Designing the Automation Bot
In the automation section, click create -> automation and give the agent version


name it ‚Äòsendemailbot‚Äô and add description as ‚Äò bot for email automation‚Äô

Click on create.

Click on setting option, go to dependencies and  click on add -> Add a business process project dependency ( it is necessary to do this as then only we can get the different operations related to outlook in our tools section )

and then add ‚Äòoutlook sdk‚Äô


Add these steps by drag & drop from the tools section ;-

  1. i) Open outlook instance
    ii) Send email(Outlook)
    iii) Release outlook instance

In automation details section, go to input/output and set one input parameter for storing the document location which is going to be attached in the mail

In Send Email(Outlook) properties, fill all necessary details
( like In emailitemparameter add custom data,
set email fields
attach file path( here add the filepath variable for storing file location))


Test the bot locally
Click on test button and give the filepath ( i.e. the folder location)
e.g.


Ensure that there are no errors.


Release the automation
Navigate to project overview
Click release ‚Äì set version 1.0.0
Add release notes : ‚Äú Initial release of outlook email bot‚Äù.

Finally Deploy the Bot
Go to deployments tab in the build lobby.
choose your bot and deploy version 1.0.0.
Assign it to a Desktop Agent that has outlook installed.
Trigger via manual execution or by scheduled trigger(e.g. every morning 9:00 am).

Benefits of this automation :-
It will save daily manual effort.
It reduces errors in repeated email content.
It ensures consistent report attachment.
It works even with outlook desktop app ‚Äì no server-side integration required.

entry.title: Find the Bug üêû Formatting dates and times in Build Apps
entry.content:
Someone sent me a problem they were having in a private message, that made me chuckle.

To be honest, after 2 years of war and 2 weeks of intense war, and having to live out of a suitcase for a week in Athens because my plane was diverted and could not enter my country -- this was a fun, amusing diversion (it actually made me laugh).

Here's the message I received:

 

FORMAT_DATETIME_WITH_TIMEZONE(DATETIME("2025-04-03T02:00:00.000Z"), "MMM d, yyyy", "America/Chicago")

 

"I am using formula to format the date. Actually the output should be Apr 2, 2025, 9 pm. But I am getting Apr 3, 2025, 9 pm. How to solve this? I tried multiple ways. It's only changing time but not date. I used other timezone format as well. Please help. This is an issue in production."

After running the formula in my Build Apps and getting the same result, I assumed it was a bug in the tool (@Mari and @Pekka_Aaltonen, please forgive me). For the programmer, the obvious thing to think was that you asked for the date in the format April 2 (because it had to give the day before because the time zone they gave was minus 6 hours from UTC) and instead it was giving April 3. Why? Probably because the formula was too stupid to return the previous day's date.

It was supposed to show this:

But kept showing this:

But, alas, there was a perfectly logical explanation, but it was hidden because of the actual date and time used in the example. Another case of all-too-human error.

Can you find the bug in the function code?

P.S.: If you like this puzzle, wait for Devtoberfest in October. We'll have plenty more.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP ‚Äì Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn‚Äôt enough,‚ÄØSAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the‚ÄØSAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video‚ÄØdemo (starting at 0:08) ‚ÄØfor more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05) ‚ÄØfor more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems‚ÄØin SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can‚ÄØ centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • SAP BTP Talk Podcast: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Import BPMN and Generate Executable Process with SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Introduction :

  • Import Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN) models and generate process artifacts automatically, for example, from SAP Signavio solutions or Netweaver BPM tools or any tool which supports process model creation as BPMN and export of the BPMN files.
  • Convert BPMN process models into an executable business process within SAP Build Process Automation

Enterprise automation with SAP Solutions:

To help customers stay ahead of the competition, SAP offers enterprise automation, a framework that combines the value of SAP Integration Suite, SAP Signavio, and SAP Build. Enterprise Automation allow customers to identify, model, integrate and automate processes end to end across heterogeneous landscapes. For more details on Enterprise Automation, please refer here.

 

Lets take an example of a process modelled in Signavio Process Manager and see how the export of the process model from Signavio Process Manager as BPMN file can be done and import of the same BPMN  file to SAP Build Process Automation helps customers with the Model to Execute pattern. This important feature helps customers to migrate their processes easily to SAP Build Process Automation without having to recreate the process from scratch.

Process Model  :

Lets take a typical use case,   Capital expenditure or capital expense (abbreviated capex, CAPEX, or CapEx), which is the money an organization or corporate entity spends to buy, maintain, or improve its fixed assets, such as buildings, vehicles, equipment, or land .

The CapEx approval process helps companies decide if big purchases are worthwhile. Most companies require multiple authorizations to approve capital expenditures, or at least those over a certain amount. This system helps prevent fraud and unnecessary purchases.

It starts off when a person or team submits a  CapEx Request Form. From there, the request usually goes through many departments on its way to the CFO/CEO. Once the CFO/CEO receives it, they take a close look and make the final call on whether to approve the purchase.

An existing Signavio customer would have modelled this process in Signavio Process Manager and executed in Signavio Process Governance. Now to switch to a low code tool SAP Build Process Automation, all that the customer has to do are outlined below :

  1.  Export process from Signavio Process Manager/Signavio Process Governance as bpmn file 
  2. Import the bpmn file to SAP Build Process Automation.(Note: If you would like to do everything yourself, you can just create a Build process automation project and proceed to Point 5. Point 1-4 helps you with a base project with some required artifacts)
    1. Go to https://github.com/SAP-samples/process-automation-enablement/tree/main/Project and download the "BPMN Import.zip" file and "CapEx_Process.bpmn" file which is exported in the previous step from Signavio Process Manager.
    2. Extract the BPMN Import.mtar file inside BPMN Import.zip
    3. Go to your Build Lobby and import the mtar file 
    4. The base project with the required artifacts are created for you .
    5. Import the CapEx_Process.bpmn file with the Import -> BPMN Process feature
  3. Do the manual configurations to make it executable ready 
    1. The imported CapEx process in Build Process Automation will have placeholders for forms, approval forms and subprocess etc., as the compatibility of the artifacts may not be one-one match with the other tool from where the process is modelled originally, in this case, Signavio Process Manager. 
    2. These placeholders will have to replaced with actual artifacts in Build Process Automation to make it executable ( Note : If the placeholders are not replaced with actual artifacts, process cannot be executed) 
    3. Guidance on what is the actual artifact is provided in placeholders . For example, if the placeholder will have to replaced with a Form, the option will say "Replace with Form", or if it has to be replaced with Action (for Service Task), it will read "Replace with Action" so on and so forth.
    4. Artifacts where there is direct compatibility like script task , mail task, conditions branch will be replaced with appropriate artifacts and content wherever applicable . 
    5. Replace the "Create Request Form" placeholder with Form
    6. Check and adjust Script task - Check Total Price of Items 
    7. Replace the "Procurement Review Subprocess" placeholder with Subprocess
    8. Replace the "Procurement Review" placeholder with Approval form 
    9. Replace the "Finance Review Approval" placeholder with Approval Form similar to the above step
    10. Check the Condition for Total price based on which CEO Approval is triggered 
    11. Replace the "CEO Approval" placeholder with Approval form similar to steps 8 and 9.
    12. Check the Mail task "CapEx Approval Status Mail" and adjust the body of the email and add recipients to make it ready for execution 
  4. Execute the process .
    1. Save and Release the project
    2. Deploy the project 
    3. Now the project is ready to be executed.
    4. Run the project from Monitoring page 

Happy Migration of your process to SAP Build Process Automation with reduced Model to Execution time !

entry.title: We asked, you answered. Customer views on SAP BTP.
entry.content:
A little over three years ago the SAP BTP team decided to develop a review page for SAP BTP with Trust Radius, a leader in enterprise software reviews, so that we might capture some feedback directly from customers concerning their satisfaction with their investment in SAP BTP, and which we hoped would also include their thoughts about the effect that use of the platform and its services was having on their own businesses.

Having now surpassed over 500 reviews, and even more ratings, as well as collecting several awards on the way, including the recent ‚ÄúTop Rated 2025‚Äù award among others, I thought that now would be a good time to reflect on some of the feedback that customers have left in their reviews of SAP BTP. 

So, here‚Äôs the first of what I hope will be a series of blogs which will look at some of the reviews that customers have left with Trust Radius about their experience with SAP BTP.  And I‚Äôve decided to do this by taking a look from different organizational viewpoints, given that reviews have been left by individuals from various roles, in different parts of the business, and from organizations of all sizes.

SAP BTP in customers‚Äô words

Let‚Äôs start with reviews from different types and sizes of organizations, and in in our customers‚Äô own words here‚Äôs what they say:

‚Äú(Company) uses BTP to manage HTML applications that are then displayed in a customer and supplier portal, we also use BTP to manage users accessing the portal and all this connected to a S4/HANA‚Ä¶SAP Business Technology Platform is the right tool to manage sites, applications, users and everything you can imagine in the cloud and non-cloud world, from my point of view BTP is very well focused and has everything that a tool has to have and today‚Äù Large media production organization, 5*review, 10000+ employees, June 2025

‚ÄúSAP Business Technology Platform is being used in our organization ‚Ä¶It's low code/ no-code so easier to integrate HANA server with non-SAP server for data sync and rapid development of the product for the production. It helps us to get real time insight of data‚Ä¶we connected our SAP servers like mm, litmos to the legacy system we have like dynamics and salesforce, which helped us a lot during data migration and system integration. It helps the entire business automation process. Easier to analyze and manage the data with beautiful dashboard. After having this much still it's cost effective‚Äù Mid-sized engineering company 5* review, 501-1000 employees, April 2025

‚ÄúBTP is used to improvise customer experience and creating automated processes across line of business and also enhancing the data and for the advanced analytics for helping in better decision-making and also BTP is a key tool for enabling the digital transformation to achieve better integration for creating more value for data and seamless flow between SAP and non SAP applications‚Äù Large IT & services business 5* review, 1001-5000 employees, May 2025

Of course, these are just a few of many reviews hosted on the SAP BTP page on the Trust Radius platform, and my selection criteria was simply one of organizational size. But even within just this small sample of customer reviews, it‚Äôs clear that SAP BTP is being used for different use cases across these differing organizations, but still delivering value through integration, automation and analytics capabilities.

Next time I‚Äôll take a look from another viewpoint, but meanwhile, if you‚Äôre already intrigued and wish to see for yourself how customers are using SAP BTP then please feel free to browse the library of SAP BTP reviews on Trust Radius, or read more about SAP BTP on our website.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
entry.content:
The APIs for process automation are quite important to building integration scenarios with processes. But many people do not know how to get started, and even experienced users do not know how to work with environments or how to handle authentication or when an API key is needed.

So here is a guide to the APIs.

NOTE: I assume that you already know how to work with process automation, and you know the ins and outs of creating and triggering process projects using the SAP Build UI.

 

What can you do with APIs

If you just use forms to trigger a process, and then the process runs with actions and approval forms, you may not need to use the APIs. But most sophisticated processes will require you to make use of the APIs. So here is a list of some of things you can do with the APIs:

  • Trigger a process (sending in input values)
  • Get the status of a process instance
  • Get the context and execution log of a process instance
  • Change the status of a process instance (such as suspend or cancel)
  • Get a list of existing processes
  • Get a list of open user tasks
  • Approve or reject an approval form
  • Execute any form, and select which button of the form to simulate pressing
  • Call a decision (business rule) to get the appropriate output
  • Get a list of automation jobs that were run
  • ... and much more

 

Where to get information on APIs

The best place to go to get basic reference information about the APIs is, of course, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Search for Process Automation, and then under APIs you will see the package of APIs.

Click the SAP Build Process Automation package, and you will see 1 OData API and 6 REST API. The key APIs are the REST APIs. 

Here's a link to get to the SAP Build Process Automation package directly.

 

Authentication and Permissions

The most complex part of working with the APIs is the authentication, and understanding the types of authentication and what each enables you to do.

2 Main Authentication Methods

There are 2 main ways to perform OAuth2 authentication:

  • Client Credentials, where you are signing in as the service, which has essentially admin rights (but not complete access to all information)
  • User Token, where you are signing in as a user (you) with whatever rights you have been given, both in terms of process automation roles and permissions in a specific SAP Build environment (more on environments later)

Why is this important?

Because you often want to know who the user is who is calling the API. For example, when triggering a process, the user who makes the API call is the one listed in the Monitoring tab. If that's not important, you can use client credentials with a service key.

Or, if you are retrieving workflow instances from an environment, only a member from that environment with the correct permissions can access the workflow instances. Using client credentials with the client id/secret will not work.

Client Credentials

To connect, with Client Credentials, you send a Client ID and Client Secret, derived from the service key.

In the cockpit, where you created an instance of the SAP Build Process Automation service, you need to create a service key. 

You only need supply a name for the key.

Once you create the key, you can view the key's detail by clicking View.

This displays something like this:

You only need the following fields to log in:

  • api: The host of the APIs
  • clientid: Username
  • clientsecret: Password
  • url: Authentication URL to get the authorization token (the URL is this URL with /oauth/token appended)

So if you were setting up a destination, this is how it would work:

User Token

But many times, perhaps most times, you do not want to use a service user but you want to know who is making the call. This is important, for example, if the call is to approve the task, so only the user to whom the task is assigned should be updating the task. Or, as we mentioned above, only a real member of an environment can retrieve workflow instances from a shared environment.

With a destination, the only change you need to make is to change the Authentication field to OAuth2JWTBearer, and this will make sure to retrieve and send a token for the current user. All other destination fields are the same.

Environments

With the relatively new shared environments (i.e., all environments except Public), you sometimes need to indicate in the API call to which environment you are making the call to. For example, a process may be deployed to multiple environments, so when you call to trigger it, you need to specify in which environment to trigger it.

To do this, you add this query parameter:

?environmentId=MyEnvironment

Similarly, if you want to retrieve all the process instances from a particular environment, your API URL might look like this:

https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-us-prod.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=danielshared

 

Try Out on Accelerator Hub

Let's try to access our SAP Build Process Automation process instances from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Go to the GET workflow-instances API. On the left menu, click Workflow Instances, and then select the first API call.

Click Add New Environment on the right, and fill in the details using the values from your service key.

Call the environment My Trial BTP, select the authentication domain for your tenant (for my trial account it was http://authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/) and then when entering the consumer subdomain, only enter the subdomain for your subaccount. 

At the bottom indicate you want to save the environment for the future, and click Configure. It might take a minute for the configuration to save.

Then, on the right, select the environment, and click Run. You should get your workflow instances.

entry.title: Gagan Mohan Singh
entry.content:
Gagan

  • New Delhi, India
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Gagan on LinkedIn

Gagan is a seasoned SAP ERP Cloud architect, business relationship manager, presales strategist and an SAP storyteller with 18+ years of hands-on delivery and quota-carrying sales experience.

Gagan started his career at IBM where he cut his SAP teeth inside the Global Business Services unit, rolling out ECC for CPG and pharma clients across India. He also rolled out several Continuous Improvement and Key Control Initiatives for PepsiCo, modernised omnichannel retail at Page Industries (Jockey & Speedo), bootstrapped an online FMCG retail start-up, worked on Presales and Program Management at NEC Corporation India and is now responsible for SAP S/4HANA (RISE and GROW)sales and Program Management at Deloitte India. He loves talking about RISE/GROW programmes in SAP and translates deep technical detail into vivid business narratives for his 65,000+ SAP related LinkedIn followers.

Topics of interest: S/4HANA ‚îÇ RISE with SAP ‚îÇ GROW WITH SAP ‚îÇ SAP BTP Extension & Integration ‚îÇ SAP Signavio ‚îÇOmnichannel Retail & CPG ‚îÇ Presales Craft & Storytelling ‚îÇ IOT ‚îÇ AI

Gagan, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

I‚Äôve always loved sharing what I learn, and giving constructive feedback, so the SAP Mentor program felt like the perfect way to scale that habit. It offers a direct, two-way channel with SAP product managers and leadership‚Äîmeaning the lessons I pick up in real projects can tangibly shape future releases‚Äîand it surrounds me with a community that‚Äôs just as passionate about raising the bar.

As someone who geeks out over the whole SAP portfolio‚Äîespecially S/4HANA, RISE with SAP, and Signavio‚ÄîI‚Äôm thrilled by the prospect of getting an early window into the new products and changes SAP is bringing to market. That behind-the-scenes insight, coupled with the chance to funnel field feedback right back to the engineers, is the part I love most.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Give back‚Äîconsistently and generously. Whether it's by participating in events, answering questions, or sharing your own learnings, every contribution strengthens the SAP ecosystem. It‚Äôs not just a way to show appreciation for what the community has given you‚Äîit‚Äôs a way to multiply value for everyone.

Make contribution a habit. Whether you're posting on SAP Blogs, writing on LinkedIn, or speaking at an Inside Track, regular engagement helps you enjoy your own work more, navigate challenges better, and build meaningful connections across the globe.

And always remember:

  • Amplify others. Celebrate their wins, share their work‚Äîit grows your network and theirs. Ultimately we win together.
  • Share the full story. Don‚Äôt just post highlights; detail it out, your lessons from failures are often what help others most.
  • Stay curious. Make time to explore new SAP tools and innovations‚Äîthis industry rewards those who keep learning.

entry.title: Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions
entry.content:
We‚Äôre thrilled to announce that Joule Studio is now GA, allowing you to deliver a tailored, agentic AI experience for your enterprise. As we go live today, you likely have questions about what the product is about, how to get started, and what to expect next. To make your journey easier, I have put together this FAQ blog that addresses the most common questions we have received from our early adopters and during the webinar.  Whether you are just exploring or ready to dive in, you will find your answers here! 

 

Product overview:  

Q: What is Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

Q: Who is Joule Studio for? 

A: Joule Studio is designed for developers who are seeking to innovate and create intelligent, conversational experiences with Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI co-pilot.  

Q: What makes Joule Studio different in the competitive landscape?  

A: Joule Studio delivers custom Joule agents and skills that are deeply grounded in business processes and data, ensuring reliable outcomes specific to your business.  

Agents delivered through standalone AI tools do not scale well in a heterogenous environment, breaking automation flows and end user experience. Joule Studio equips customers with an open and extensible framework that connects not only SAP but also non-SAP systems and models. That enables agents and skills to scale and execute efficiently.  

Security is the top concern for any enterprise, and Joule Studio delivers that. Developers can leverage built-in security and privacy enforcement, such as data masking and data filtering, to ensure compliance with AI interactions.  

Joule Studio delivers most business focused agents and skills that together extend Joule and drive business efficiency.  

Q: What are the key capabilities of Joule Studio? 

A: SAP Build empowers customers to expand Joule‚Äôs capabilities and adapt them to diverse business needs through two key components: 

  • Custom Joule Skills: Joule Studio enables the creation of tailored, business-specific Joule skills with flexibly defined logic and third-party integrations, ensuring adaptability and maximizing value. For example, retrieving weather conditions from a third-party API or vendor risks from risk management software.  
  • Custom Joule Agents: Joule Studio supports the development of custom AI Agents, leveraging data from SAP and non-SAP sources to plan and execute complex business scenarios, and enhance decision-making processes. For example, a logistic agent that optimizes shipment delivery routes based on real time data such as weather conditions, carrier availability, and other aspects.  

 

Conceptual: 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and AI agents? 

A: It is important to note the technical differences between custom Joule agents and skills. Below table summarizes it - 

 

 

Joule skills 

AI agents 

Aspects 

Are part of an advanced AI model, and can act on specific operation, by leveraging the context of the conversation 

Are autonomous, multi-tool systems that solve complex problems by selecting and executing appropriate tools dynamically 

Purpose 

Single, predefined and repetitive, atomic operations 

Multi-step, adaptive problem solving 

Complexity 

Simple operations with known inputs/outputs 

Complex, dynamic workflows 

Flexibility 

Limited to predefined actions 

Highly flexible and goal-oriented 

Integration 

Specific APIs via SAP Build actions 

Multi-tool orchestration 

Resource consumption 

Minimal resource consumption 

More resource-intense due to its use of large language models 

 

Q: Is there a list of Joule Skills available and can standard skills be customized? 

A: Standard Joule Skills can be explored in the discovery center, while custom Joule skills will be managed from the Lobby of your SAP Build tenant. In the first release, standard skills will not be customizable. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and SBPA automations?  

A: Joule Skills act as the essential wrapper for automation built within SAP Build. They expose these processes to the Joule and custom agents in a secure and structured way. If you want Joule to trigger an automation ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a workflow, a bot, or a system task ‚Äî you can wrap that logic in a Joule Skill. This allows the Joule and agents to understand what it can do, when it can do it, and how to safely execute it on behalf of the user. 

Q: How do I orchestrate different skills and agents?  

A: These are triggered and orchestrated via Joule based on user intent. So, Joule might call a custom skill to report compliance of vendors or an agent for setting up interviews with a candidate based on user intent and context of conversation. 

Q: What are use cases of Joule skills and AI agents? 

A: Common use cases of Joule Skills include navigation, workflow execution, and decision assistance. Skills can help users navigate specific information or documentation; collect inputs and execute structured workflows; and enhance decision-making by providing predefined insights. 

For agents, common use cases can involve both complex tasks and enterprise-wide executions. Agents handle complex, multistep workflows that require reasoning, adaptability, and contextual awareness. Unlike deterministic automation tools, agents can dynamically adjust processes based on changing business conditions and evolving data inputs. AI agents also bridge disparate systems and business domains‚Äîfacilitating automations across an enterprise, breaking operational silos, and connecting fragmented IT landscapes. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Studio and SAP Joule for Developers? 

A: Here, we should draw a clear distinction: Joule for Developers is a collection of AI powered features designed to assist developers in their day-to-day tasks, making activities such as writing code, creating processes, and performing technical operations easier and more efficient with the help of Joule's conversational AI capabilities. 

On the other hand, Joule Studio is evolving into a distinct product within the SAP Build family, focused specifically on building conversational experiences through an agentic approach. Joule Studio is where developers accelerate innovation by creating intelligent, conversational agents that make everyday tasks easier for business users. These agents will augment the workflows and processes that run your business and enhance organizational efficiency.  

In summary, while Joule for Developers optimizes the developer experience, Joule Studio will drive a broader transformation of how work gets done, accelerate innovation and improve usability for both technical teams and business users. 

 

Deployment & Data integration:  

Q: In which regions is Joule Studio available and what version of SAP S/4HANA does it work with (public or private)? 

A: Joule Studio is globally available across US, Europe, and Australia. Please refer to link. There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. So, it works with both public and private cloud versions.   

Q: Do we need to provision the SAP Build in the same tenant as we have Joule to build Joule Skills and agents? 

A: This documentation provides the exact details for setup of Joule Studio via a booster to connect SAP Build and Joule tenants. 

Q: Is it possible to integrate Joule Studio with on premise SAP S/4HANA and is there a minimum version for SAP S/4 HANA required for that integration? 

A: Custom Joule skills and agents can call APIs and BAPIs (via Actions) and Process Automation (built in SAP Build) to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems, meaning you will need to get any cloud solution with Joule, for example SAP Start or Build Work Zone. 

There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. 

Q: Can Joule Agent be exposed for on premise deployment after building it on cloud?  

A: Custom Joule agents can call APIs and Process Automations to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via a Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems. 

 Q: Is it possible to use data products from SAP Datasphere? 

A: Yes, if you can retrieve this data via API. 

 

Security, Compliance, and Privacy:  

Q: How is personal data protected in prompts sent to agents and LLMs? 

A: Data privacy controls, such as data masking and data filtering, are enforced through the orchestration module of AI core. 

Q: What security roles are needed for the agents to function? 

A: Joule follows the principle of propagation, and both Joule Skills and conversational AI Agents will continue to follow this principle. That means any agent or skill will act within the same security bounds as the user who is chatting with Joule has, inheriting their access and permissions as well. 

 

Availability and Getting Started: 

Q: Is Joule Studio available now? What features are currently available, and what is coming soon? 

A: As of today, developers can access Joule Studio directly from SAP Build lobby and create Joule Skills within Joule Studio. 

Custom AI Agents - General Availability is targeted for the second half of 2025. 

Q: How to get started with Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio is now generally available, allowing you to extend and tailor Joule with custom Joule skills. To use Joule Studio, you‚Äôll need Joule Base (or higher) and an SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311). With these, you can build, test, and deploy custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio at no additional cost‚Äîaside from the standard execution and runtime charges for the automations, apps, and processes that Joule orchestrates. 

Q: Is SAP Business Data Cloud a prerequisite? 

A: No, SAP Business Data Cloud is not a prerequisite.  

Q: Are there any learning and training resources available to upskill on Joule Studio?  

A: Yes, we have published a learning journey and a tutorial and will release a mission as well for Joule Studio. Please look out for a resource blog in the coming days compiling all resources.   

Q: Are there guided experiences to try Joule Studio?  

A: Yes ‚Äì we are working on a basic trial experience for Joule Studio which will be published in the coming weeks. There are product tour and interactive value journeys available as guided experiences.  

Q: Is Joule Studio part of the SAP BTP free trial?  

A: No, Joule Studio will not be available on the SAP BTP free trial. We are working on a basic trial and other guided experiences as indicated above.  

Q: How can partners get access to Joule Studio now ‚Äì is there a test environment or special program? 

A: We plan to have a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license ready by the end of July, with dependency on SAP Build Everything and Joule Base. Please look out for future updates. 

Q: Can partners build Joule skills & agents and publish them to a store? 

A: Not in the first release - where partners will need to develop these capabilities on the customers' tenants with the necessary configurations. For future updates, we are exploring a store for partner agents and skills. 

Q: If I already have a Build license, can I start using Joule Studio? 

A: You will need an SAP Build developer license to access Joule Studio. If you have any of the older SAP Build licenses, you will not be able to access Joule Studio seamlessly. 

Seamless migration from existing SAP Build services to this SKU is not supported for now.  As a result, some manual configuration will be required at the subaccount level. 

Subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan on another subaccount and ensure that this SAP BTP subaccount includes a subscription to SAP Build Process Automation (set up documentation and mission for reference). 

Manual export and import between subaccounts are required to reuse existing SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) projects, automations, and processes. This limitation applies only to content created prior to the transition. Any new content developed within the new environment will not be affected. 

 

Final remarks: 

I hope this blog answered your questions and helped you feel more confident about getting started with Joule Studio. We‚Äôre incredibly excited about what this launch means for our customers and partners and can‚Äôt wait to see how they use it to solve unique scenarios. As always, we‚Äôre here to support you ‚Äî don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out for questions, feedback, or ideas.

entry.title: Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation
entry.content:
Access Joule Studio from the SAP Build Lobby.

For modern enterprises, we know that harnessing the full potential of business data is essential to making smarter decisions and accelerating innovation. To truly deliver impact, AI agents must go beyond traditional automation ‚Äì they need to plan and adapt execution based on real-time data and human input. To get the most accurate and relevant results, they need a deep understanding of your unique business data and processes.

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre excited to announce the general availability of Joule Studio in SAP Build. With Joule Studio, developers can now start to tailor and extend SAP‚Äôs agentic AI to businesses, accelerate workflow automation, and unlock even greater value.

Joule Studio is the latest SAP Build capability where you can extend Joule‚Äôs out-of-the-box capabilities with company-specific skills and intelligent agents.

In case you missed it, see the announcement and overview of Joule Studio to understand the unique value it brings deep grounding in business processes & data, an open and extensible framework, and built-in Security & Compliance.

In this post, I‚Äôll share more about what‚Äôs available today: custom Joule skills creation in Joule Studio, along with key capabilities, typical use case patterns, and resources for getting started. I‚Äôll also share a sneak peek at what lies ahead with custom AI agents in Joule Studio and how they‚Äôll continue to evolve to support even more complex, cross-system business scenarios.

What are Joule skills?

With today's general availability release, it‚Äôs now possible to start expanding Joule‚Äôs capabilities using Joule Skills, built with skill builder in Joule Studio, to handle repetitive, rule-based tasks.

Joule skills are modular components within Joule. They leverage the contents of a conversation to complete a specific task.

Here‚Äôs a closer look at the key attributes of Joule Skills:

  • Deterministic execution: Joule Skills perform single, predefined operations. These operations can contain multiple steps, such as automations or messages. Each operation contains fixed inputs and outputs, ensuring consistent and efficient results.
  • Natural language understanding: Joule interprets different ways a user might request an operation, ensuring the correct skill is triggered, regardless of phrasing.
  • Context awareness: Joule analyzes user roles, conversation history, and business context to trigger skills only when relevant, avoiding unnecessary executions.
  • Multiple skills working together: Joule Skills are published within a single productive Joule instance, seamlessly combining SAP-provided and custom skills for a unified automation experience.

Joule skills are modular and self-contained, meaning that organizations can start leveraging them to automate everyday tasks without having to add extra layers of complexity. With Joule Studio‚Äôs open and extensible framework, skills can be integrated with SAP apps, as well as third-party APIs through SAP Build actions, so they can carry out tasks across systems automatically without needing extra steps or human input.

Explore custom skills further in the Joule Studio product tour.

Typical Use Case Patterns

Joule skills are ideal for handling common, low-complexity requests, freeing your team‚Äôs time up from routine tasks. Let‚Äôs take a look at some of the common use cases for creating custom Joule skills:

  • Navigation: Allow users to navigate seamlessly across company applications to find specific information, such as IT help resources and HR policies.
  • Data access: Enable users to retrieve, monitor, and track data such as shipping info or optimized delivery routes with real-time traffic updates.
  • System transactions: Structured workflows and system transactions ‚Äî like IT ticket creation or order management ‚Äî can be automated and executed via Joule.
  • Workflow execution: Enable Joule to initiate workflow and collect user input for requirements, such as hiring approval processes, facility maintenance requests, or supplier contract renewals.
  • Decision assistance: Enhance decision-making by providing pre-defined insights, such as credit risk evaluation, sales performance forecasting and warehouse demand predictions.

Of course, these only begin to cover the breadth of possibilities that Joule skills offer, as they‚Äôre deeply grounded in business data and processes. As part of SAP Build, Joule Studio has native access to all your connectors, automations, apps, and actions ‚Äî enabling you to reuse assets, leverage shared APIs, and operate within a single governance framework. This tight integration eliminates duplication, accelerates delivery, and ensures consistency across your SAP Build environment. With Joule Studio‚Äôs intelligent understanding of existing automations and applications, the skills developers build are not only tailored to unique business needs but also drive real-world outcomes. 

For a deeper understanding of how Joule Studio can integrate and extend SAP and non-SAP solutions, refer to the SAP Reference Architecture within the Architecture Center: https://url.sap/xw5uq7

Several of our SAP Partners have already started to transform their everyday operations with Joule Studio and custom skills. To learn more about their use cases and experiences, check out their blog posts:

  • How sovanta uses Joule Studio to take ticketing systems to the next level
  • How Pricefx is transforming pricing software with Joule Studio in SAP Build
  • How LeverX enhances CAD Data Search for Manufacturing with Joule Studio in SAP Build

Get started creating custom Joule Skills

As we move closer to a more unified experience across SAP Build, the skill-building process is designed to feel intuitive and familiar. Joule Studio makes it easy to dive in and get started, with a setup that feels instantly familiar to anyone who's used SAP Build.

The typical design process includes:

  1. Creating a project in SAP Build: Directly from the SAP Build Lobby, initiate the skill development environment within Joule Studio.
  2. Defining metadata: Add the skill name and description to ensure discoverability, semantic clarity and intent-based Joule orchestration.
  3. Configuring inputs and outputs: Determine what Joule will request from the end user (inputs) and what it will return (outputs), enabling structured communication.
  4. Building the logic flow: Embed existing automation elements such as actions, decisions, and sub-processes with a familiar drag-and-drop simplicity.
  5. Test in the Test Environment: Test how newly created Joule Skill works within the Joule conversation. Ensure that it functions as expected and does not conflict with any other existing Joule Skills.
  6. Release and Deploy to Production: Make project available to end users by deploying it to the specified production environment.

Following SAP Build‚Äôs approach, Joule Studio enables both developers and business process experts to start creating. So, whether you‚Äôre an enterprise architect looking to extend Joule for your organization‚Äôs AI solutions, or a line of business expert hoping to simplify routine requests ‚Äì Joule Studio now lets you create custom skills with drag-and-drop ease and maximum adaptability.

Completed custom Joule Skill

For a step-by-step guide on creating custom skills, check out the Interactive Value Journey: Designing custom Joule skills in Joule Studio

What‚Äôs Next: Pushing the boundaries with custom AI Agents

This is only the beginning for Joule Studio, as we‚Äôll continue to evolve the capabilities further by introducing the agent builder in Joule Studio later this year. With custom AI agents, enterprises can unlock even more complex scenarios, bridging across multiple systems, steps, and tasks.

AI agents used for procurement scenariosHere‚Äôs a few examples of what would be possible with custom AI agents:

  • Procurement decision-making: Analyze supplier performance and market trends, helping procurement teams make informed decisions, negotiate better contracts, and ensure supply chain reliability.
  • Talent acquisition: Streamline the recruitment process by reviewing candidates based on resumes, scheduling interviews, and assisting in onboarding (e.g. gathering docs), ensuring faster and efficient hiring.
  • Logistics planning: Optimize delivery routes based on real-time traffic data, weather conditions, and carrier availability, enhancing efficiency and reducing transportation costs.

To understand more about fundamental differences between a Joule skill and agent, read this blog.

Designing a custom AI Agent in Joule Studio. With the general availability of Joule Studio, this marks a meaningful step forward in how work gets done‚Äîmoving from traditional, linear automation to intelligent, adaptive systems that can handle real-world complexity. As organizations begin to explore their potential, Joule Studio will help teams work smarter, respond faster, and unlock new levels of efficiency across the enterprise.

Learn more about how to access Joule Studio and get started: Read the blog post

entry.title: How to Get Started with Joule Studio
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Miguel Angel Meza Martinez and Maria Kondratyeva

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency.

 

Skill Builder in Joule Studio is now Generally Available

At the heart of Joule Studio are custom Joule Skills ‚Äî purpose-built, reusable logic blocks that can be tailored to your unique business needs. These skills support flexible logic and seamless integration with third-party systems, unlocking automation opportunities across domains. Whether it's retrieving weather data from an external API to inform transport planning, or assessing vendor risks via your risk management platform, Custom Joule Skills let you adapt quickly and deliver real business value.

As Joule Studio reaches General Availability, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question:

‚ÄúWhat are the commercial and technical implications of working with Joule Studio?‚Äù

Whether you're a business decision-maker evaluating impact, a developer preparing your technical landscape, or a partner planning ahead for trial licenses ‚Äî this post outlines what you need to know to get started smoothly and cost-effectively.

Pre-Requisites

Before you dive into building with Joule Studio, make sure your environment includes:

SAP Build

    • Leverage Cloud Integration Automation service scenario for SAP Build to install SAP Build Process Automation service.
    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher).

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it‚Äôs important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free , the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule Skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation (BTPEA) will still be billed according to the BTPEA pricing structure.

Partner Access ‚Äì TDD License

For our partners, we recognize how important it is to test, demonstrate, and develop with Joule Studio. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre preparing a TDD (Test, Demo, Development) license, which is expected to be ready in the upcoming months. This license will be built on top of SAP Build and Joule. We‚Äôll be sharing updates and specific guidance as we get closer to a release date.

Technical Setup

To ensure proper functionality of Joule Studio within an SAP BTP environment, a defined technical setup process is required. This process establishes secure identity trust, enables core service dependencies, and configures cross-component communication essential for custom Joule Skills orchestration and runtime execution.

At the core of the setup is the need to establish trust between your SAP BTP subaccount and your Identity Authentication tenant.  This trust configuration is mandatory to enable user authentication and token-based authorization flows between Joule Studio and other SAP services.

Concurrently, it is necessary to map user attributes within the SAP Cloud Identity Directory. These attribute mappings (e.g., email, user ID, first name, last name, groups, etc.) are used to support user context resolution and enforce authorization policies during skill execution.

Following trust and attribute configuration, the Joule Booster must be executed. This booster is a guided setup workflow available in SAP BTP and is responsible for:

  • Automatically provisioning required service instances and entitlements
  • Binding SAP Build (build_default service plan) to a productive Joule instance
  • Activating SAP Cloud Identity Services dependencies
  • Validating identity configuration and connectivity across services

The full technical configuration process is documented in the official Joule Studio Set-Up Guide, available in the SAP Help Portal. It is strongly recommended that system administrators follow the documentation precisely, as manual misconfiguration can result in authentication failures, missing service bindings, or broken orchestration flows.

Migration Considerations for Existing SAP Build Customers

Currently, there is no automated or seamless migration path for customers who have previously subscribed to standalone SAP Build services under older SKUs or who have developed content in subaccounts that are not aligned with the new license model required by Joule Studio.

This means that some manual configuration is required at the BTP subaccount level if you wish to transition existing SBPA projects into a new Joule-enabled environment.

Manual Configuration Steps:

  • You will need to create a new SAP BTP subaccount and subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan associated with the new SKU.
  • Within this subaccount, make sure you also subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation, as it is a foundational runtime component for custom Joule Skills that trigger workflows or automations.

Once the new subaccount is configured, you can manually migrate existing SBPA content (such as processes, and automations) using export and import functionality provided by SAP Build tools. It‚Äôs important to note that this process is not automatic and may require some post-import validation to ensure dependencies (e.g., destinations, service bindings, user roles) are correctly mapped in the new environment.

This limitation applies only to content developed prior to the transition. Once you are operating within the Joule-enabled subaccount, all newly created content will be natively compatible with Joule Studio and will not require further migration effort.

This is a one-time effort but depending on the complexity of your current SBPA landscape, it may require significant administrative coordination ‚Äî especially if your original environment includes cross-system integrations, custom scripting logic, or a large number of interdependent workflows.

üí°Tip: Before initiating a full migration, consider whether all existing content truly needs to be moved. In many cases, only selected automations and apps need to be reused or triggered from the new environment, while other can continue to run temporarily in the original tenant. This can reduce complexity and allow for a phased migration strategy, where only the most critical elements are prioritized for transition, while others are gradually retired, redesigned, or rebuilt in Joule Studio as needed.

Looking Ahead: What‚Äôs Next

Joule Studio is launching with a clear, accessible model: no AI Unit consumption and no additional orchestration cost for custom Joule Skills built with current features. This gives teams a solid foundation to explore, prototype, and scale ‚Äî without friction.

But this is only the start.

Looking ahead, new SAP Build license will introduce a pay-as-you-go (PAYG) model, providing greater flexibility for customers to adopt Joule Studio capabilities incrementally ‚Äî without needing a full upfront subscription. This is especially valuable for teams piloting new use cases or scaling adoption gradually.

In addition, a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license is planned to support SAP partners with dedicated, hands-on environments for prototyping and showcasing Joule-enabled experiences.

As the Joule Studio evolves ‚Äî with features like AI Agents on the horizon ‚Äî the commercial model may adapt to reflect expanded functionality. Any changes will be communicated clearly and ahead of time.

 

Get to Know Joule Studio 

üì∞Deep Dive Blog 

üíæArchitecture Overview

üìπJoule Skill Demo Video

üìπSmart Advisory Companion ‚Äì Inspiration Video

üß≠ Product Tour

‚ùìFAQ

entry.title: Joule Studio Empowers Enterprises to Build Intelligent AI Skills
entry.content:
Authors: @Trinidad & @jacobahtan 

As businesses adopt AI at an accelerated pace, the need for AI tools that deeply understand enterprise processes becomes critical. SAP Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot, is designed to address this need‚Äîoffering intelligent, contextual, and secure assistance across the SAP ecosystem.

But what if the out-of-the-box AI capabilities don‚Äôt fully match your business needs? Enter SAP Joule Studio, a powerful low-code tool that enables you to build your own Joule Skills, tailor-made for your organization‚Äôs workflows.

This blog explores how Joule Studio empowers companies to create custom AI skills, automate repetitive tasks, and seamlessly integrate AI into daily operations.

This is a summary of the business use case I presented together with my colleague @Trinidad in this webinar: Amplify Joule's power for your enterprise needs. Please, note the mentioned session is part of a series of webinars under the topic of ‚ÄúTalk to Your Business with Generative AI‚Äù. Check the full calendar here to watch the recordings of past sessions and register for the upcoming one.

 

üí° What is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is an AI copilot designed to provide intelligent, contextual assistance within the SAP ecosystem. Unlike generic AI chatbots, Joule understands SAP business processes, user context, and role-based permissions, allowing it to deliver meaningful, secure, and actionable responses.

üåê Unified Across the SAP Ecosystem

  • Joule acts as a single AI instance connected to SAP Cloud solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).
  • Users can interact with Joule via an embedded web client, mobile interface (e.g., SAP Mobile Start), or third-party tools like Microsoft Teams.
  • Regardless of the entry point, Joule maintains user context, security, and session continuity.

ü§ñ Joule's Capabilities: How Does It Work?

When a user interacts with Joule, here‚Äôs what happens under the hood

  1. User Input: A natural language query is entered e.g., ‚ÄúShow me open purchase orders for customer ABC.‚Äù

  2. Intent Recognition: Joule checks if the query matches:
    • An out-of-the-box skill (prebuilt by SAP)
    • A custom skill developed by the partner/customer
    • Or if it requires a knowledge-based response (e.g., documents or help articles)

  3. Knowledge Filtering: Joule pulls information from:
    • SAP documentation
    • The customer‚Äôs own document repositories (document grounding)
    • Application-specific data (e.g., SAP S/4HANA)

  4. Context Gathering:
    • Who is the user?
    • What are their roles, permissions, and session context?
    • What application are they working in?

  5. Query Orchestration:
    • Joule composes an enriched, context-aware query.
    • This is passed to a Large Language Model (LLM) like GPT or Gemini for dialogue generation.

  6. Skill Execution:
    • If the response requires action (e.g., ‚ÄúCreate a service ticket‚Äù), Joule invokes the appropriate skill or API.

  7. Response Delivery:
    • The answer or action is returned to the user, formatted appropriately (e.g., text, links, buttons).

‚öôÔ∏è Joule Skills vs. AI Agents: Understanding the Difference

üîß Joule Skills: Deterministic Automation

Purpose: Automate structured, repetitive tasks with predefined logic.
How it works: When a query matches a defined intent, the corresponding skill executes a fixed workflow.
Example Use Cases:

  • Checking contract validity
  • Retrieving customer orders
  • Creating service tickets

Characteristics:

  • Rule-based
  • Fast and reliable
  • Requires clear input/output definitions

üß†  AI Agents: Dynamic, Reasoning-Powered Automation (Coming Soon)

Purpose: Handle complex tasks with ambiguous goals, requiring reasoning and decision-making.
How it works:

  • Breaks tasks into subtasks autonomously
  • Chooses which APIs, skills, or tools to use
  • Adjusts the execution path based on real-time context

Example Use Cases:

  • Supply chain disruption management (e.g., predicting and mitigating shipment delays)
  • Cross-system troubleshooting with adaptive workflows

Characteristics:

  • Autonomous planning
  • Uses LLMs for reasoning
  • Dynamic execution paths

üîë In Simple Terms

Skills: ‚ÄúTell me what to do, and I‚Äôll do it.‚Äù

Agents: ‚ÄúTell me the goal, and I‚Äôll figure out how to get there.‚Äù

 

Joule Studio

... is a new tool within SAP Build that lets partners, developers, and customers create, manage, and deploy Joule Skills‚Äîcustom AI-driven capabilities that extend the functionality of SAP Joule.

‚úÖ Why Joule Studio Matters

  • Automates routine tasks using natural language.
  • Provides an easy-to-use, low-code/no-code interface.
  • Empowers business users and developers to extend SAP Joule without writing extensive code.
  • Seamlessly integrates with both SAP systems and third-party applications.

üéØ Business Value
